cpt_codes_used.31641: Bronchoscopy; with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method
cpt_codes_used.31625: Bronchoscopy; with bronchial or endobronchial biopsy(s) (used in some debridement cases)

notes.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
Photodynamic Therapy - Light Application Session

Patient Name: Rodriguez, James
Age/Sex: 62/M
MRN: 4744854
Date of Service: February 22, 2024
Procedure Start Time: 13:15
Procedure Duration: 88 minutes
Attending Physician: Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD


PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma, Right lower lobe bronchus, T1aN0M0 (Stage IA1), patient declined surgery

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Same

PROCEDURES PERFORMED
1. Photodynamic therapy - laser light application (CPT 31641)
2. Flexible bronchoscopy with tumor measurement and documentation

PHOTOSENSITIZER ADMINISTRATION
Agent: Porfimer sodium (Photofrin)
Dose: 2.0 mg/kg IV
Total dose administered: 116.0 mg (patient weight 58 kg)
Administration date/time: February 20, 2024 at 15:00 hours
Time from photosensitizer to light: 48 hours (within optimal therapeutic window)

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. Robert Miller (attending), Samantha Lee CRNA

MONITORING
Standard ASA monitors including continuous pulse oximetry, end-tidal CO2, and arterial line monitoring.

EQUIPMENT
- Olympus BF-1T180 therapeutic bronchoscope
- Cylindrical diffusing fiber (3.0cm length, 400 micron core diameter)
- Diode laser system: 630nm wavelength
- Light dosimetry calculation performed pre-procedure

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed verifying correct patient, procedure, and photosensitizer administration timing.

Initial Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. Systematic examination revealed normal upper airways and trachea. The carina appeared sharp and normal. The endobronchial tumor was identified in the Right lower lobe bronchus.

Tumor Characteristics (Pre-PDT measurements):
- Location: Right lower lobe bronchus
- Size: 1.2cm (longitudinal) × 1.1cm (circumferential extent)
- Morphology: Flat, plaque-like lesion
- Surface: Irregular surface, non-bleeding
- Obstruction: Approximately 54% luminal narrowing
- Distal airways: Patent beyond the lesion

Photodynamic Therapy Light Delivery:
Laser safety protocols confirmed (room signage, protective eyewear, fire safety measures in place). The cylindrical diffusing fiber was introduced through the working channel of the bronchoscope. The fiber was positioned to center the tumor within the treatment field.

Treatment Parameters:
- Wavelength: 630 nm (optimal for Porfimer activation)
- Power output: 400 mW/cm of diffuser length
- Diffuser length: 3.0 cm
- Total power: 1200.0 mW (1.2 W)
- Light dose (fluence): 200 J/cm² of diffuser surface
- Treatment time: 500 seconds (8 minutes 20 seconds)

Light was continuously delivered for the calculated duration. During light application, laser energy meter verified consistent power output. No visible tissue changes during light delivery (expected for PDT mechanism). No charring or thermal effects observed, confirming non-thermal photochemical mechanism. Patient remained hemodynamically stable throughout with no arrhythmias or oxygen desaturations.

Post-Treatment Assessment:
Immediately following light delivery, the treated area appeared essentially unchanged (expected for PDT - tissue necrosis develops over 24-72 hours). No immediate edema or bleeding noted. The fiber was removed and the bronchoscope withdrawn.

Light Precautions Review:
Post-procedure, the following light precautions were reviewed with patient and family:
1. Strict avoidance of direct sunlight and bright indoor lights for 30 days minimum
2. Wear protective clothing, wide-brimmed hat, gloves when outdoors
3. Gradual re-exposure to normal light starting day 30 with skin testing
4. Emergency contact information provided
5. Written instructions given

The patient tolerated the procedure well. Extubated in the OR without difficulty. Transferred to PACU in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
None (non-excisional therapy)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal

COMPLICATIONS
None

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
This 62-year-old male with T1aN0M0 endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma (Right lower lobe bronchus), who is patient declined surgery, underwent photodynamic therapy light application session without complications.

Timeline for Follow-up:
1. Scheduled debridement bronchoscopy: February 24, 2024 (48 hours post-light)
2. Anticipated findings: Necrotic tumor debris requiring mechanical removal
3. Will assess treatment response and consider biopsies from treatment bed

Ongoing Management:
- Continue light precautions (patient education reinforced)
- Monitor for post-PDT complications: airway edema, photosensitivity reactions
- Dexamethasone 4mg PO BID x 5 days (reduce airway inflammation)
- PPI therapy (reduce risk of esophageal photosensitivity)

Long-term surveillance:
Bronchoscopic surveillance at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment per protocol.

Electronically signed by: Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD
Date/Time: February 22, 2024 14:43

registry_entry.primary_indication: Endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma, Right lower lobe bronchus, T1aN0M0 (Stage IA1), patient declined surgery

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopic photodynamic therapy light application constitutes tumor destruction. CPT 31641 is the appropriate code for destruction by any method.

31641.description: Bronchoscopy; with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method

coding_review.overall_assessment: Correctly coded as 31641 for PDT light application. No biopsies or other separately reportable services documented.

notes.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
Photodynamic Therapy - Post-PDT Debridement Session

Patient Name: Williams, Thomas
Age/Sex: 79/M
MRN: 9937326
Date of Service: March 05, 2024
Procedure Start Time: 11:45
Procedure Duration: 72 minutes
Attending Physician: Dr. Michael Patel, MD


PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Status post photodynamic therapy for endobronchial mucoepidermoid carcinoma, Left lower lobe bronchus, 48 hours post-light application

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Same; necrotic tumor debris successfully debrided

PROCEDURES PERFORMED
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with debridement of necrotic tissue (CPT 31641)
2. Endobronchial biopsy of treatment bed

CLINICAL HISTORY
This 79-year-old male underwent photodynamic therapy light application on March 03, 2024 for endobronchial mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the Left lower lobe bronchus. The patient now presents for scheduled debridement bronchoscopy at 48 hours post-light to remove anticipated necrotic tumor debris.

Interval History:
- No significant respiratory distress since PDT
- Minimal symptoms since procedure
- Light precautions maintained
- No photosensitivity reactions

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (7.5mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. Robert Miller (attending), David Wilson CRNA

EQUIPMENT
- Fujifilm EB-580T therapeutic bronchoscope
- Biopsy forceps
- rigid coring
- Suction apparatus

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed.

Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. The upper airways and trachea appeared normal. The carina was sharp.

PDT Treatment Site Assessment:
Examination of the Left lower lobe bronchus revealed expected findings 48 hours post-PDT:
- Significant necrotic debris overlying the previous tumor site
- Gray-brown necrotic tissue with sloughing appearance
- Pre-debridement airway obstruction: approximately 52%
- Surrounding mucosa with mild erythema (expected post-PDT inflammatory response)
- No active bleeding at treatment site

Debridement Procedure:
Using rigid coring, the necrotic tumor debris was systematically removed. Multiple passes were required to adequately clear the airway. 



Post-Debridement Assessment:
- Airway patency significantly improved
- Post-debridement obstruction: approximately 27%
- Treatment bed visible with granulation tissue formation
- No active bleeding following debridement
- Distal airways now fully patent and accessible

Biopsies of Treatment Bed:
Multiple biopsies (x4) were obtained from the treatment bed periphery to assess for residual viable tumor. Specimens sent for pathology.

The bronchoscope was withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated without difficulty.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsies (x4) from treatment bed - sent for pathology

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Negligible

COMPLICATIONS
None

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
This 79-year-old male, 48 hours post-PDT for endobronchial mucoepidermoid carcinoma, underwent successful debridement bronchoscopy with improvement in airway patency from 52% to 27% obstruction.

PDT Response Assessment:
- Moderate response to PDT based on extent of tumor necrosis
- Airway significantly improved
- Biopsies pending to confirm complete tumor ablation

Plan:
1. Continue light precautions until day 30 post-initial PDT
2. Await pathology results
3. Repeat debridement if needed based on clinical status
4. Surveillance bronchoscopy scheduled in 8 weeks
5. Chest CT in 6-8 weeks to assess treatment response

Electronically signed by: Dr. Michael Patel, MD
Date/Time: March 05, 2024 12:57

Status post photodynamic therapy for endobronchial adenocarcinoma, Left lower lobe bronchus, 72 hours post-light application

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Same; necrotic tumor debris successfully debrided

PROCEDURES PERFORMED
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with debridement of necrotic tissue (CPT 31641)


CLINICAL HISTORY
This 57-year-old male underwent photodynamic therapy light application on April 28, 2024 for endobronchial adenocarcinoma of the Left lower lobe bronchus. The patient now presents for scheduled debridement bronchoscopy at 72 hours post-light to remove anticipated necrotic tumor debris.

Interval History:
- No significant respiratory distress since PDT
- Minimal symptoms since procedure
- Light precautions maintained
- No photosensitivity reactions

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.5mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. Karen Liu (attending), Jennifer Brown CRNA

EQUIPMENT
- Fujifilm EB-580T therapeutic bronchoscope
- 
- microdebrider
- Suction apparatus

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed.

Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. The upper airways and trachea appeared normal. The carina was sharp.

PDT Treatment Site Assessment:
Examination of the Left lower lobe bronchus revealed expected findings 72 hours post-PDT:
- Significant necrotic debris overlying the previous tumor site
- Gray-brown necrotic tissue with friable appearance
- Pre-debridement airway obstruction: approximately 66%
- Surrounding mucosa with mild erythema (expected post-PDT inflammatory response)
- No active bleeding at treatment site

Debridement Procedure:
Using microdebrider, the necrotic tumor debris was systematically removed. Multiple passes were required to adequately clear the airway. 



Post-Debridement Assessment:
- Airway patency significantly improved
- Post-debridement obstruction: approximately 11%
- Treatment bed visible with granulation tissue formation
- No active bleeding following debridement
- Distal airways now fully patent and accessible




The bronchoscope was withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated without difficulty.

SPECIMENS
Necrotic debris removed - not sent for pathology (post-treatment tissue)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Negligible

COMPLICATIONS
None

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
This 57-year-old male, 72 hours post-PDT for endobronchial adenocarcinoma, underwent successful debridement bronchoscopy with improvement in airway patency from 66% to 11% obstruction.

PDT Response Assessment:
- Excellent response to PDT based on extent of tumor necrosis
- Airway significantly improved
- Consider surveillance bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks

Plan:
1. Continue light precautions until day 30 post-initial PDT
2. No biopsies taken - plan surveillance bronchoscopy
3. No further debridement anticipated
4. Surveillance bronchoscopy scheduled in 8 weeks
5. Chest CT in 6-8 weeks to assess treatment response

Electronically signed by: Dr. Christopher Lee, MD
Date/Time: May 01, 2024 09:12

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Same; necrotic tumor debris successfully debrided

PROCEDURES PERFORMED
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with debridement of necrotic tissue (CPT 31641)


CLINICAL HISTORY
This 69-year-old male underwent photodynamic therapy light application on August 02, 2024 for endobronchial large cell carcinoma of the Left upper lobe bronchus. The patient now presents for scheduled debridement bronchoscopy at 48 hours post-light to remove anticipated necrotic tumor debris.

Interval History:
- No significant respiratory distress since PDT
- Mild increased cough with brownish sputum production
- Light precautions maintained
- No photosensitivity reactions

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (7.5mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. Karen Liu (attending), David Wilson CRNA

EQUIPMENT
- Fujifilm EB-580T therapeutic bronchoscope
- 
- biopsy forceps, rigid coring, cryoprobe
- Suction apparatus

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed.

Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. The upper airways and trachea appeared normal. The carina was sharp.

PDT Treatment Site Assessment:
Examination of the Left upper lobe bronchus revealed expected findings 48 hours post-PDT:
- Significant necrotic debris overlying the previous tumor site
- Gray-brown necrotic tissue with sloughing appearance
- Pre-debridement airway obstruction: approximately 74%
- Surrounding mucosa with mild erythema (expected post-PDT inflammatory response)
- No active bleeding at treatment site

Debridement Procedure:
Using biopsy forceps and rigid coring and cryoprobe, the necrotic tumor debris was systematically removed. Multiple passes were required to adequately clear the airway. 

Cryotherapy was used to assist with removal of adherent necrotic tissue.

Post-Debridement Assessment:
- Airway patency significantly improved
- Post-debridement obstruction: approximately 5%
- Treatment bed visible with clean mucosal base
- No active bleeding following debridement
- Distal airways now fully patent and accessible




The bronchoscope was withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated without difficulty.

SPECIMENS
Necrotic debris removed - not sent for pathology (post-treatment tissue)

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal (< 10 mL)

COMPLICATIONS
None

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
This 69-year-old male, 48 hours post-PDT for endobronchial large cell carcinoma, underwent successful debridement bronchoscopy with improvement in airway patency from 74% to 5% obstruction.

PDT Response Assessment:
- Excellent response to PDT based on extent of tumor necrosis
- Airway significantly improved
- Consider surveillance bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks

Plan:
1. Continue light precautions until day 30 post-initial PDT
2. No biopsies taken - plan surveillance bronchoscopy
3. No further debridement anticipated
4. Surveillance bronchoscopy scheduled in 6 weeks
5. Chest CT in 6-8 weeks to assess treatment response

Electronically signed by: Dr. Jennifer Walsh, MD
Date/Time: August 04, 2024 08:55

Same; necrotic tumor debris successfully debrided

CLINICAL HISTORY
This 64-year-old female underwent photodynamic therapy light application on January 26, 2024 for endobronchial carcinoid tumor of the Left mainstem bronchus. The patient now presents for scheduled debridement bronchoscopy at 96 hours post-light to remove anticipated necrotic tumor debris.

Interval History:
- No significant respiratory distress since PDT
- Mild increased cough with brownish sputum production
- Light precautions maintained
- No photosensitivity reactions

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.5mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. William Park (attending), Michael Adams CRNA

EQUIPMENT
- Fujifilm EB-580T therapeutic bronchoscope
- 
- rigid coring, suction catheter, biopsy forceps
- Suction apparatus

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed.

Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. The upper airways and trachea appeared normal. The carina was sharp.

PDT Treatment Site Assessment:
Examination of the Left mainstem bronchus revealed expected findings 96 hours post-PDT:
- Significant necrotic debris overlying the previous tumor site
- Gray-brown necrotic tissue with friable appearance
- Pre-debridement airway obstruction: approximately 72%
- Surrounding mucosa with mild erythema (expected post-PDT inflammatory response)
- No active bleeding at treatment site

Debridement Procedure:
Using rigid coring and suction catheter and biopsy forceps, the necrotic tumor debris was systematically removed. Multiple passes were required to adequately clear the airway. Intermittent suctioning was used to clear debris and maintain visualization.



Post-Debridement Assessment:
- Airway patency significantly improved
- Post-debridement obstruction: approximately 7%
- Treatment bed visible with granulation tissue formation
- No active bleeding following debridement
- Distal airways now fully patent and accessible




The bronchoscope was withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated without difficulty.

None

PDT Response Assessment:
- Excellent response to PDT based on extent of tumor necrosis
- Airway significantly improved
- Consider surveillance bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks

Plan:
1. Continue light precautions until day 30 post-initial PDT
2. No biopsies taken - plan surveillance bronchoscopy
3. No further debridement anticipated
4. Surveillance bronchoscopy scheduled in 8 weeks
5. Chest CT in 6-8 weeks to assess treatment response

Patient Name: Davis, Richard
Age/Sex: 63/M
MRN: 7640184
Date of Service: March 08, 2024
Procedure Start Time: 10:30
Procedure Duration: 38 minutes
Attending Physician: Dr. Amanda Foster, MD
Assistant: Dr. Lisa Martinez, Fellow

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Status post photodynamic therapy for endobronchial large cell carcinoma, Left upper lobe bronchus, 96 hours post-light application

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Same; necrotic tumor debris successfully debrided

PROCEDURES PERFORMED
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with debridement of necrotic tissue (CPT 31641)
2. Endobronchial biopsy of treatment bed

CLINICAL HISTORY
This 63-year-old male underwent photodynamic therapy light application on March 04, 2024 for endobronchial large cell carcinoma of the Left upper lobe bronchus. The patient now presents for scheduled debridement bronchoscopy at 96 hours post-light to remove anticipated necrotic tumor debris.

Interval History:
- No significant respiratory distress since PDT
- Minimal symptoms since procedure
- Light precautions maintained
- No photosensitivity reactions

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (7.5mm ETT)
Anesthesia team: Dr. Robert Miller (attending), Samantha Lee CRNA

EQUIPMENT
- Olympus BF-1T180 therapeutic bronchoscope
- Biopsy forceps
- rigid coring, biopsy forceps
- Suction apparatus

DETAILED PROCEDURE NARRATIVE
The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite. After successful induction of general anesthesia and orotracheal intubation, a time-out was performed.

Bronchoscopic Survey:
The bronchoscope was introduced through the endotracheal tube. The upper airways and trachea appeared normal. The carina was sharp.

PDT Treatment Site Assessment:
Examination of the Left upper lobe bronchus revealed expected findings 96 hours post-PDT:
- Significant necrotic debris overlying the previous tumor site
- Gray-brown necrotic tissue with friable appearance
- Pre-debridement airway obstruction: approximately 44%
- Surrounding mucosa with mild erythema (expected post-PDT inflammatory response)
- No active bleeding at treatment site

Debridement Procedure:
Using rigid coring and biopsy forceps, the necrotic tumor debris was systematically removed. Multiple passes were required to adequately clear the airway. 



Post-Debridement Assessment:
- Airway patency significantly improved
- Post-debridement obstruction: approximately 22%
- Treatment bed visible with clean mucosal base
- No active bleeding following debridement
- Distal airways now fully patent and accessible

Biopsies of Treatment Bed:
Multiple biopsies (x3) were obtained from the treatment bed periphery to assess for residual viable tumor. Specimens sent for pathology.

The bronchoscope was withdrawn. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was extubated without difficulty.

SPECIMENS
Endobronchial biopsies (x5) from treatment bed - sent for pathology

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimal (< 10 mL)

COMPLICATIONS
None

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
This 63-year-old male, 96 hours post-PDT for endobronchial large cell carcinoma, underwent successful debridement bronchoscopy with improvement in airway patency from 44% to 22% obstruction.

PDT Response Assessment:
- Good response to PDT based on extent of tumor necrosis
- Airway significantly improved
- Biopsies pending to confirm complete tumor ablation

Plan:
1. Continue light precautions until day 30 post-initial PDT
2. Await pathology results
3. Repeat debridement if needed based on clinical status
4. Surveillance bronchoscopy scheduled in 4 weeks
5. Chest CT in 6-8 weeks to assess treatment response

Electronically signed by: Dr. Amanda Foster, MD
Date/Time: March 08, 2024 10:08
